verses.text: A wise ruler brings order to his people, and the government of a prudent man is well established.
verses.comment: Leadership grounded in wisdom brings stability and peace. This echoes Solomon's example, whose wisdom upheld the nation. Wise governance has deep spiritual implications as well, reflecting God's order in creation and the organization of the faithful.

verses.text: As the judge of the people is himself, so are his officials; as the ruler of a city is, so are all its inhabitants.
verses.comment: A community often mirrors its leaders. Holiness and justice in leadership cultivate virtue in the people, hinting at the necessity for spiritual guidance from those in authority—pointing toward a divinely ordered and hierarchical Church model.

verses.text: An unwise ruler destroys his people, but cities prosper through prudent leadership.
verses.comment: The health of a nation depends on sound rule. Just as earthly societies need guidance, the faithful require shepherds. Spiritual oversight is stressed here, aligning with the intention for a visible, ordered Church.

verses.text: The authority over the earth is in the hand of the Lord, and at the right time he will raise up the right ruler.
verses.comment: Divine providence guides human history. God sets up leaders according to His wisdom. The verse resonates with the concept of apostolic succession and divinely appointed authority among Christ's followers.

verses.text: The prosperity of a man is in the hand of the Lord; he covers the face of the scribe with shame, and he will lift up his head.
verses.comment: God alone ordains success and humbles the proud. The scribe, a teacher of the law, is only honored through God’s will—hinting at the sanctity of those who teach right doctrine.

verses.text: Do not be angry with your neighbor for every wrong, and do not act out your anger with violence.
verses.comment: The call to slow anger reflects Jesus’ commands against wrath (Matt. 5:22). This virtue is a prerequisite for true reconciliation and peace, essential elements of the Church’s teachings on forgiveness.

verses.text: Pride is hateful before the Lord and before humanity, and injustice is both sinful and offensive.
verses.comment: Pride separates people from God and others. Humility and justice are necessary for communion with God, prefiguring the need for sacramental confession as a means of grace.

verses.text: Dominion passes from one nation to another because of injustice, violence, and pride.
verses.comment: Historic shifts in power remind us that pride and injustice bring downfall. God’s providence is showcased in world events, calling for humility and obedience in spiritual life.

verses.text: Why do those who are earth and ashes become proud? Even in life, his body decays.
verses.comment: Remembering mortality and frailty helps cultivate humility. The link to Genesis 3:19 grounds this wisdom in the reality of the Fall, calling believers to depend on the promise of resurrection in Christ.

verses.text: A long illness makes a person forget pride; even a mighty man can die.
verses.comment: Suffering and illness teach dependence on God rather than self. The Christian response to suffering is not despair, but trust in divine mercy.

verses.text: When a person has died, he inherits worms and decay, and his pride is forgotten.
verses.comment: Earthly honors fade. This prepares the soul for the sobering reality of judgment, which calls for humility and readiness through works of mercy.

verses.text: The beginning of pride is when one forsakes the Lord, and his heart turns away from his Maker.
verses.comment: Pride is at the root of separation from God. True faith involves submission and recognizing dependency on divine grace, echoing the attitude of the saints.

verses.text: For pride brings disaster, and eventually God brings its destruction.
verses.comment: The repeated biblical warning against pride underscores God’s desire for a contrite heart. Disaster resulting from pride is a motif throughout Scripture, culminating in the need for repentance.

verses.text: The Lord has overthrown the thrones of rulers and has seated the humble in their place.
verses.comment: Mary’s Magnificat echoes this verse, where God raises the humble and brings down the mighty. The reversal theme is central in the New Testament, showing God’s favor on those who submit to His will.

verses.text: The Lord has uprooted proud nations and planted the lowly in their place.
verses.comment: Nations boasting of power are replaced by those who are humble. Ultimately, God’s kingdom is given to those who are meek, as taught in the Beatitudes (Matt. 5:5).

verses.text: The Lord has wiped out the memory of proud rulers and established the lowly in perpetuity.
verses.comment: History testifies to God’s judgment on arrogance. Being remembered forever is a spiritual promise, alluding to the honor given to saints and those who live humble service.

verses.text: Pride was not created for humanity, nor fierce anger for those born of women.
verses.comment: God’s design for human nature excludes pride and rage. Holiness, humility, and peace reflect the image of Christ.

verses.text: What race has honor? The human race. What race has honor among them? Those who fear the Lord. What race has no honor? Those who break the commandments.
verses.comment: Honor is found not in ancestry, but in reverence for God and obedience. This teaches the universality of God’s call—every nation invited, but distinguished by obedience and fear of the Lord.

verses.text: The leader is honored among his brothers, but the Lord’s fear is greater than both.
verses.comment: Human leadership is valuable, yet fearing the Lord ranks higher. This echoes the spiritual principle of humility and obedience to God above all.

verses.text: The rich, the honorable, and the poor—one can glory in fearing the Lord.
verses.comment: Social distinctions are secondary to reverence for God. The spiritual riches found in holy fear surpass all worldly status.

verses.text: It is not right to despise the poor or to honor the sinner.
verses.comment: Both poverty and sin are to be understood within the context of God’s mercy. The poor are to be respected, and sinners admonished, reflecting the community responsibility found in the Church.

verses.text: The noble, the judge, and the ruler are to be honored, but none is greater than the one who fears the Lord.
verses.comment: Fear of the Lord surpasses all human rank. Within the community of believers, spiritual virtue takes precedence over worldly title.

verses.text: The wise steward among his people guards himself against shame, but the bold and shameless will be hated.
verses.comment: True wisdom involves restraint and self-control. Spiritual stewardship is key for those who are entrusted with responsibility in the Church.

verses.text: Honor is due to the rich, the wise, and the diligent worker, but greater honor is reserved for those who fear the Lord.
verses.comment: God rewards both the successful and the spiritual, but those who devote themselves to holiness are given greater dignity—pointing to the special place of saints in the community.

verses.text: A poor person who has wisdom lifts his head high and sits among the great.
verses.comment: Wisdom, not wealth, brings true exaltation. This prefigures Christ’s assertion that the last will be first (Luke 14:10), and the humble raised up.

verses.text: Do not seek what is above you, nor examine matters beyond your strength.
verses.comment: Humility in knowledge is emphasized, keeping focus on revealed truth rather than speculation. Trusting authority and tradition is a safeguard against error.

verses.text: Consider what has been commanded to you, for you have no need of hidden things.
verses.comment: Obedience to known commands rather than seeking secret things is commended. The believer is reminded to focus on what God has revealed through Scripture and tradition.

verses.text: Do not involve yourself in unnecessary matters, for more has been revealed to you than men can understand.
verses.comment: Keeping to one’s responsibilities allows deeper understanding of revealed truths, avoiding distraction and division in the community.

verses.text: Many have been misled by their own reasoning, and false opinion has undermined their judgment.
verses.comment: Human intellect is not infallible—objective truth is to be received rather than constructed, reinforcing the value of teaching authority.

verses.text: A stubborn heart will fare badly in the end, and the one who loves danger will perish in it.
verses.comment: Rebellion and disregard for wisdom leads to ruin. Fidelity is the safeguard for salvation.

verses.text: A proud heart brings division; evil plants deep roots, and its end is disaster.
verses.comment: Divisiveness is born of pride, threatening the unity of God’s people. The emphasis on unity here prepares believers for embracing the fullness of faith in the one apostolic Church.
